summary: A letter written in December 2020 to Judge Alison Nathan from a friend of Ghislaine Maxwell, defending Maxwell's character. The writer describes how Maxwell provided her with free housing in London after the writer's husband died, leaving her destitute. The letter asserts Maxwell's innocence and pleads for humane treatment.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: The Honorable Alison Nathan is the judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York to whom this letter is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the letter. The writer, a friend for over 25 years, defends Maxwell's moral character, describing her kindness in providing free housing and asserting her innocence against the charges she faces.

connections.description: Friends for over 25 years. Maxwell provided the writer with free housing in London after the writer's husband died.
The writer's deceased husband, who was an old friend of Ghislaine Maxwell and introduced them.
Old friends who first met in Hong Kong in the early 1990s.

events.title: Character Letter Submission
events.description: A friend of Ghislaine Maxwell writes a letter to Judge Alison Nathan defending Maxwell's character and pleading for her humane treatment while awaiting trial.

events.title: Meeting in Hong Kong
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell first met the letter writer's husband in Hong Kong.

events.title: Death of Writer's Husband
events.description: The letter writer's husband died approximately three years prior to December 2020, leaving her destitute.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The document is a character reference letter written to Judge Alison Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell in December 2020.
The writer, a friend of Maxwell for over 25 years, states that Maxwell provided her with free housing in London after the writer's husband died, leaving her destitute and homeless.
The writer asserts that Ghislaine Maxwell is innocent of the charges against her and deserves due process and humane treatment.
The letter reveals a personal, long-term friendship between Maxwell and the writer, initiated by the writer's husband who was an old friend of Maxwell's from Hong Kong in the early 1990s.
